awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Proposal: Linking physiology and morphology in Grassland evolution via a novel analytical technique
awd_abstract_narration:
Grasslands cover ~40% of Earth’s land surface, playing a key role in terrestrial life, global climate and critical human resources (the grass family includes all cereal crops like rice and wheat). Although they appeared ~70 million years ago, the spread of grasslands began only ~22 million years ago, with tropical savanna ecosystems present by ~8 million years ago. Grass evolution and ecosystem change likely coincided with evolving climates, landscapes and animals. The best way to identify fossil grasses is from microscopic silica pieces (“phytoliths”), left behind in sedimentary rocks when the rest of the plant has decomposed. Phytoliths have shapes characteristic of particular grass types, but no method exists that can reveal the photosynthesis type (C3 or C4) of the grass that produced them. This project tests a new method to use phytoliths to measure the chemistry of un-decomposed carbon inside them; thus, the photosynthetic type of the grasses that produced them. This will allow researchers to answer questions about the past and possible future of grasslands. For example, what grasses grew in the earliest savannas and what photosynthesis did they use? What caused the spread of the C4 grasses, and what will happen as Earth’s atmosphere and climate continue to change? 
 
This cross-disciplinary project will utilize precision sample preparation and in-situ analytical methods to characterize 1. the distribution of disseminated and occluded carbon in phytoliths, and 2. the carbon isotopic ratios of these reservoirs, reflecting photosynthetic pathway. The project will first compare leaf and phytolith chemistry of greenhouse-grown specimens and move on to soils with the ultimate goal of application to fossil systems. The proposed method, once fully developed, can be executed at many laboratories world-wide and will represent a major leap forward in analytical phytology. This work will have applications to a wide range of topics including the relationships between grassland and hominid evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical-subtropical savannas and grasslands today are dominated by grasses that use so-called C4 photosynthesis. This type of photosynthesis allows these “C4 grasses” to flourish under hot and/or dry conditions where other grasses with the ancestral type of photosynthesis (“C3“), would not do well. C4 grasses are currently responsible for ~25% of Earth’s terrestrial primary production, and provide habitat and food (e.g., maize, sugarcane) for millions of humans and other animals. The rapid spread of C4 grasses across the tropics happened only 8-5 million years ago, >20 million years after the first C4 grasses evolved from C3 grasses. Understanding how the evolution and spread of C4 grasses shaped modern grassland ecosystems is important for predicting how they might change in an increasingly warm world. To do so, paleontologists use the shapes of silica particles, so-called phytoliths, made by different grasses. However, although phytoliths can tell you the group of grasses it came from, it cannot tell you if it was a C4 or C3 grass. Our project sought to develop a novel way of measuring the chemistry of an individual phytolith to determine the photosynthetic pathway of the grass it came from. Specifically, we our goal was to design a protocol that would allow us to use Secondary Ionization Mass Spectrometry (nanoSIMS) to study stable carbon isotopes contained in phytoliths from plants and soil. This had never been done before because, until recently, the laser beam that the nanoSIMS uses to measure stable carbon isotopes was much wider than the phytoliths themselves.

To design this new method and make it sufficiently robust and precise, we had to do a lot of experimentation on every detail and every step that it involves. Although the nanoSIMS now can produce a narrow beam, it is still very difficult to measure small amounts of carbon contained in the grass phytoliths, which are often less than 10 microns across. Our work so far has resulted in a protocol for how to (1) extract and clean phytoliths from modern grasses and soils, (2) construct a mount where extracted phytoliths can be deposited and safely transported before they are pressed and polished for analysis, (3) detect the phytoliths in the nanoSIMS, and (4) measure the stable carbon isotope composition in individual phytoliths. We have devised a silica “standard” to which we can compare our raw values and translate them into values that can be interpreted in terms of C3 and C4 photosynthesis. We have also characterized the dominant phytolith shapes in our modern grass samples, so that we can combine the information from phytolith morphology with the isotopic data. Along the way, we have learnt that the isotopic signature of grass phytoliths is more complex than that of grass tissues. Now that we have a rough protocol, we will continue to measure the stable carbon isotopes of our samples and standards to make the method more robust and precise. We will further refine our method by studying the morphology and carbon isotopic signature of grass phytoliths in soils and, eventually, in fossil samples.

The intellectual merit of this project is that it will result in a new, much more precise way to track the evolution of C4 grasses and grasslands, allowing us to better understand the factors that influence the evolution of these ecosystems. In turn, this will help us predict and mitigate how C4 grasses, which make up a large part of our food supply and habitats, might respond to increasingly warmer climates. Our method is also producing information about how different grasses make phytoliths, providing insights into their physiology.

The broader impacts of the research is in the form of research training, mentoring, and professional development within a female-only group of scientists, including women graduate students from underserved groups in STEM. Through the project, these women scientists, which are at different stages of their career (graduate students to junior and senior faculty), have created a strong collaboration and mentoring ladder in a field where women often lack role models and close women collaborators. For example, all of the PIs have children, and have been able to share their experiences navigating their careers while also being caregivers and dealing with prejudice.
